The white dashes on the left of the bike lane also serve as guidance lines for vehicles to stay away from. After the intersection, there is also a similarly sized bike lane. status_notes: Case Noted. The Boston Transportation does its best to maintain a steady flow of traffic throughout the day and evening. We make adjustments to signal timing when applicable to help improve traffic flow. We also alert the Boston Police and/or the Massachusetts State Police of when there may be an irregular flow of traffic. We are able to view certain areas of the City through a live feed from cameras to our Traffic Management Center; which allows us to make adjustments to the signal timing. We do not however have the authority or the capability to make signal adjustments to traffic signals owned by other authorities. The City of Boston and the Transportation Department apologize for any inconvenience the traffic congestion has caused you. status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you for submitting both your request for bike lanes and your observations of violations of traffic regulations. The parking protected bike infrastructure on Mass Ave in the Back Bay has been recently completed as part of the Vision Zero program in the City. While we understand that the facilities are in substandard condition, due to the recent snow/weather, BTD & PWD teams are working to identify and clear snow, debris, etc from all corridor spaces as quickly as possible.  In the early Spring, flexposts will be surveyed and replaced where needed. Regarding the violations of the traffic signal, BTD (even the Bikes & Planning folks) do not support or endorse the disregard for any traffic control device or regulatory sign by ANY roadway user. Safety is of the highest priority; and minimizing the unintended effects of mistakes made is a primary tenant of the Vision Zero program. Cyclists violating the red light of a traffic signal is the same as a motorist disregarding that a light has turned from yellow to red, and endangering users from other street approaches. If you continue to see such behavior exhibited by ANY roadway users, please submit a direct CRM with only that item to the BPD queue. Without the lane/infrastructure request, their constituent services agents can respond to you.
description: Please paint bike lanes on Mass Ave from Boylston to Huntington. Have witnessed several accidents involving bicyclists with both vehicles and pedestrians. status_notes: Case Noted. Thank you so much for submitting your support for bicycle infrastructure on Charles Street in Beacon Hill!  This corridor is certainly on our priority list for inclusion into larger network redesigns, and we hope to move them forward as soon as possible. The Charles Street corridor has substantial excess width over what is required for processing the vehicular traffic. We are aware of the increasing demand for some of that space to return to pedestrian use, and other space to be dedicated to cycling facilities.  BTD Planning will be working with various other City departments, as well as the neighborhood association for Beacon Hill, in order to reallocate and rethink the use of space on this very important street.  We hope that you will remain involved and vocal about supporting biking and safer infrastructure, both in Beacon Hill, and City-wide.
